botanical_details.potentially_harmful: Ingestion may cause a severe discomfort. Skin irritant. Wear gloves and other protective equipment when handling.
botanical_details.genus: Helleborus can be rhizomatous, herbaceous or semi-evergreen perennials forming a clump of pedate basal leaves, or evergreen with erect, leafy stems. Large, bowl-shaped flowers are borne in loose clusters in late winter or spring

how_to_grow.cultivation: Tolerant of a range of moisture retentive, humus-rich soils in light shade but best in fertile, neutral to alkaline soils that are not prone to drying out in summer. For more advice, see hellebore cultivation
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate large clumps by division in early spring or early autumn. and water well until established; plants propagated by seed may be variable
how_to_grow.pruning: Remove old leaves to expose the flowers and control hellebore leaf spot in winter before the flowers start appearing and deadhead by removing the old faded flower stems
how_to_grow.pests: May be susceptible to hellebore aphids, slugs and snails
how_to_grow.diseases: May be susceptible to hellebore leaf spot, hellebore black death, grey mould (botrytis) and virus diseases
